properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing drizzle expected tonight. Freezing drizzle has developed over Northwestern Ontario and will persist tonight. Patches of dense fog may also develop tonight. Travel may be affected due to icy roads and reduced visibilities at times. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-25T14:24:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-25T00:51:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2490188249.2019
Area: Pickle Lake - Cat Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hazardous winter conditions is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 70 km/h. Time span: continuing until Boxing Day. Locations: Grand Falls-Windsor to the Baie Verte Peninsula. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will continue into tonight. Gusty northeasterly winds will also develop later today and will strengthen to strong northwesterlies with gusts to 70 km/h overnight tonight. Snow will become lighter and more intermittent for Christmas Day and Boxing Day, but the strong northwesterly winds will persist, resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-25T06:09:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-24T14:10:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0803302036.2019
Area: Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls will continue into tonight. Total snowfall: locally 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h causing blowing snow. Locations: Victoria county and Inverness county north of Mabou, especially over the Highlands. Time span: tonight with conditions improving Christmas morning. Remarks: Flurries, heavy at times, will continue tonight before tapering off Christmas morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-25T11:59:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-25T02:12:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1689760100.2019
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions near the Richardson Mountains are expected to continue until late Wednesday afternoon. Current indications are that blizzard conditions may redevelop over the Dempster Highway on Thursday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-25T10:35:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-24T18:36:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0345995029.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Locations: Postville and Makkovik. Timespan: ending near midnight. Remarks: The freezing drizzle is expected to transition to scattered flurries near midnight. ### Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-25T07:59:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-24T19:56:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2239207665.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are possible tonight. Total snowfall: locally 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 km/h causing some blowing snow. Locations: Pictou, Antigonish and Inverness county south of Mabou. Time span: tonight. Remarks: Flurries, heavy at times, will continue tonight before tapering off Christmas morning. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-25T14:14:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-25T02:11:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2811411599.2019
Area: Pictou County, Antigonish County, Inverness County - south of Mabou
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Additional snowfall: 5 to 10 cm tonight. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h, except 100 km/h in the Bonavista area. Time span: continuing until late tonight. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will begin again this evening and continue through much of the night tonight. Winds will increase from the northeast with gusts to 70 km/h along parts of the coast this evening, before shifting to strong northwesterly winds gusting to 80 to 100 km/h early Christmas morning. While the snow will ease overnight tonight, the strong northwesterly winds will persist through Christmas Day and Boxing Day, causing blowing snow at times. In addition, a second round of steadier snow, possibly heavy, is expected to develop by the afternoon on Boxing Day. Further details on accumulations for this period will be provided as more information becomes available. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-25T11:32:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-24T19:33:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4011931367.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values near minus 50 are expected again tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-25T14:51:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-24T23:55:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2645856410.2019
Area: Old Crow
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring over some areas. Areas of dense fog will slowly dissipate Wednesday morning to the afternoon hours. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hazardous winter conditions is expected. Additional snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Time span: continuing until Boxing Day night. Locations: Gander and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will continue into tonight. The snow will become lighter and more intermittent on Christmas Day, before a second round of heavy snow sets in the morning of Boxing Day. Gusty northeasterly winds will develop tonight and strengthen to strong northwesterlies with gusts to 80 km/h overnight. The strong northwesterlies will then persist through Boxing Day. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Additional snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 km/h. Locations: Grand Falls-Windsor to the Baie Verte Peninsula. Time span: continuing until Boxing Day. Remarks: Snow will continue into tonight. Northeasterly winds gusting to 50 km/h will strengthen to strong northwesterlies with gusts to 70 km/h overnight tonight. Snow will become lighter and more intermittent for Christmas Day and Boxing Day, but the strong northwesterly winds will persist, resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-25T11:26:55-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea water levels are expected later this week. Wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: east and northeast coasts of Newfoundland. Time span: Thursday and Friday. Remarks: a prolonged period of strong winds will cause very large waves to build later this week. Storm surge and coastal flooding may occur along shorelines exposed to the north and northeast, especially near the high tides. The highest water levels are expected to occur on Friday morning, but vulnerable areas may become susceptible to flooding as early as the Thursday morning high tide. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-25T11:25:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-24T19:26:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3812797600.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada
